original_data.question: A 55-year-old man presents with complaints of exertional dyspnea and dry cough. He reports using extra pillows at night to sleep and two nighttime awakenings to catch his breath in the last month. The patient lives in a homeless shelter and has not seen a doctor in the last 20 years. He has been drinking 5-8 drinks of alcohol per day for the last 20 years. Family history is non-significant, and the patient does not take any medications. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), blood pressure is 135/115 mm Hg, pulse is 85/min, and respiratory rate is 24/min. Physical examination reveals 2+ bilateral pitting edema. Chest auscultation reveals bibasilar crackles. Which of the following is associated with this patient’s condition?

model_response:
The patient’s signs and symptoms are consistent with heart failure. The most common cause of heart failure is coronary artery disease, and the patient should be evaluated for this condition. The patient’s history of alcohol abuse raises the possibility of alcoholic cardiomyopathy. The patient’s signs and symptoms are also consistent with fluid overload, which can be caused by decreased renal sodium excretion. This can be secondary to decreased renal blood flow, which can be caused by decreased cardiac output. The decreased cardiac output can be secondary to left ventricular dysfunction, which can be caused by alcoholic cardiomyopathy.

Answer: OPTION D IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
A symptom or problem for which a patient seeks medical attention.
Perceived difficulty to breathe that occurs with exercise or exertion and improves with rest. [PMID:29763022]
A cough that is not accompanied by expectorated secretions.
Detailed account or statement or formal record of the proceedings of a meeting or session. May also document status or progress of an activity or research project.
A cushion or support for the head or other body part; usually consisting of a cloth case surrounding a filler of feathers, down, plastic fibers, latex, rubber, or other foam material.
The time in every 24 hour period when it is dark.
A readily reversible suspension of sensorimotor interaction with the environment, usually associated with recumbency and immobility.
The time in every 24 hour period when it is dark.
To wake up or become awake.
A sudden pain, usually sharp, occurring during movement, or exacerbated by movement, and prompting cessation of movement
The air that is inhaled and exhaled during respiration.
Every month.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Housing created or provided for ILL-HOUSED PERSONS.
Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
Behaviors associated with the ingesting of ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES, including social drinking.
A single serving of a beverage; any liquid suitable for drinking.

A clear, colorless liquid rapidly absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract and distributed throughout the body. It has bactericidal activity and is used often as a topical disinfectant. It is widely used as a solvent and preservative in pharmaceutical preparations as well as serving as the primary ingredient in ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and disease events of blood relatives. A patient's family medical history may be important in diagnosing existing conditions.

A term applied to differences, correlations, cause-and-effect relationships, etc., to indicate that they are noticeable, probably too closely correlated to be attributed to chance and therefore indicating a systematic relation: substantial, fairly large; also having consequence or import, important in effect or meaning. In statistics significant ordinarily indicates a probability of not less than 95 percent, while highly significant indicates a probability of not less than 99 percent.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Drugs intended for human or veterinary use, presented in their finished dosage form. Included here are materials used in the preparation and/or formulation of the finished dosage form.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.
The rate of breathing (inhalation and exhalation) measured within in a unit time, usually expressed as breaths per minute.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.

Swelling due to excessive accumulation of fluid under the skin defined by a persistent indentation when pressure is applied to the swollen area. Causes include systemic conditions (e.g., heart failure, liver failure, or kidney failure) and local conditions affecting the extremities.
The upper part of the trunk between the NECK and the ABDOMEN. It contains the chief organs of the circulatory and respiratory systems. (From Stedman, 25th ed)
Act of listening for sounds within the body.
Joined in some kind of relationship.
A description of the physiological status of a patient.
